response.answer_text: A sequence {x(n)} in a metric-space (X, d) is said to be convergent sequence , converging to x ∈ X, if for any given ε > 0, there exist a positive integer n₀ such that d(x(n), x) < ε for n >/= n₀ or equivalently if lim(n→∞){d(x(n), x)} → 0 . For example the sequence {1/n} is a convergent sequence, converging to 0 in the metric-space (R, μ) (set of real numbers with standard metric), because ; lim(n→∞)|1/n - 0| = lim(n→∞){1/n} = 0 etc.
